questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement in a patient with diminished night vision and the following finding?

options.label: B
options.text: ERG shows loss of A & B wave amplitude

options.label: C
options.text: Night blindness is a late feature

options.label: D
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

questions.correct_answer: C. Night blindness is a late feature
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Night blindness is a late feature Image shows bony spicule pigmentation is suggestive of Retinitis pigmentosa. Night blindness is the characteristic and earliest feature in Retinitis Pigmentosa.

Highyeild:

RETINITIS PIGMENTOSA Most common type- Autosomal recessive. Rod- Cone dystrophy. Visual Symptoms Night blindness- It is the characteristic and earliest feature . Dark adaptation- Light Threshold Of The Peripheral retina is increased. Tubular vision, i.e. loss of peripheral vision with preservation of central vision occurs in advanced cases. Central vision is also lost ultimately after many years. Fundus changes Retinal pigmentary changes- These are typically perivascular (around veins) and jet black spots resembling bone corpuscles shape. Retinal Arterioles Are Attenuated(narrowed). Thinning and atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) . Optic disc becomes pale and waxy in later stages and ultimately consecutive optic atrophy occurs. Visual Field changes Annular or ring-shaped scotoma - As the disease progresses, scotoma increases anteriorly and posteriorly and ultimately only central vision is left (tubular vision). Electrophysiological changes Electroretinogram (ERG) is initially subnormal (scotopic affected before photopic; b-wave affected before a wave) and eventually extinguished. Electro-oculogram (EOG) is subnormal with an absence of light peak.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Most common rod-cone dystrophy is a true statement. Option: B. ERG shows loss of A & B wave amplitude is also a true statement. Option: D. Loss of peripheral vision is a late presentation in Retinitis Pigmentosa.

questions.text: A patient of RHD presents with a superior visual field defect in the left eye for 1 week, what is the cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Branch retinal artery occlusion Rheumatic heart disease leads to the formation of emboli and this emboli causes Branch retinal artery occlusion.

Highyeild:

BRANCHED RETINAL ARTERY OCCLUSION It usually occurs following lodgement of embolus at a bifurcation. Retina distal to occlusion becomes oedematous with narrowed arterioles. Later on the involved area is atrophied leading to permanent sectoral visual field defect.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Superior visual field defect in this Patient rules out Central retinal artery occlusion. Option: B. Superior visual field defect in this Patients rules out Central retinal vein occlusion. Option: D. Rheumatic heart disease patients have a tendency to form emboli, hence Branch retinal vein occlusion is ruled out.

questions.text: A laborer working in a construction site comes to casualty with red eyes and a history of Chuna particle falls 1 hour back. How will you manage this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Patch the eye after topical lubricants

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Irrigation with Normal Saline Chuna particle is made up of lime which is an alkali. Since the injury happened 1 hour back, it is an acute presentation , hence initial earliest management will be Irrigation with Normal saline to reduce the time of insult.

Highyeild:

Treatment of chemical burns Prevent further damage by following measures Immediate and thorough irrigation with the available clean water or saline delivered through an IV tubing. Do not waste time on history and examination of the patient; it should be done after the irrigation. Mechanical Removal Of Contaminant- If Any Particles are left behind, particularly in the case of lime, these should be removed carefully with a swab stick. Removal of contaminated and necrotic tissue. Necrosed conjunctiva should be excised. Contaminated and necrosed corneal epithelium should be removed with a cotton swab stick. Maintenance of favourable conditions for rapid and uncomplicated healing by following measures Topical Antibiotic Drops. Steroid eye drops to reduce inflammation. Lubricant eye drops (preservative free) should be used in abundance to promote the healing. Topical ascorbic acid.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Topical antibiotics and cycloplegics are given later. Option: C. Patch the eye after topical lubricants is never done. Option: D. Temporary tarsorrhaphy is also never done.

questions.text: All of the following are actions of superior oblique except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adduction Superior oblique does not cause adduction.

Highyeild:

ACTIONS OF EXTRAOCULAR MUSCLES Muscle Primary action Secondary action Tertiary action LR Abduction _ _ SR Elevation Intorsion Adduction IR Depression Extorsion Adduction SO Intorsion Depression Abduction I0 Extorsion Elevation Abduction

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Superior oblique causes depression. Option: C. Superior oblique causes abduction. Option: D. Superior oblique causes intorsion.

questions.text: The following are features of Ocular (3rd) nerve palsy except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Limited abduction Limited abduction is not seen in Third nerve palsy. It is a feature of Lateral rectus palsy.

Highyeild:

Clinical features of Paralysis of the third cranial nerve Ptosis due to paralysis of the LPS muscle. Deviation- Eyeball is turned down, out and slightly intorted due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Ocular movements are limited in all the directions except outward. Pupil is fixed and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle. Accommodation is completely lost due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle. Crossed diplopia is elicited on raising the eyelid. Head posture may be changed if pupillary area remains uncovered.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Exotropia & hypotropia are seen in third nerve palsy due to paralysis of superior rectus, inferior oblique and medial rectus muscles. Option: B. Ptosis is due to paralysis of the LPS muscle. Option: C. Pupil is fixed and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle.

questions.text: The following is the most common cause of proptosis in middle aged individuals?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Thyroid eye disease Most common cause of proptosis in middle aged individuals is Thyroid eye disease.

Highyeild:

Most common cause of unilateral proptosis in adults is Thyroid associated ophthalmopathy (Grave’s disease). Most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children is Orbital cellulitis. Most common cause of Bilateral proptosis in adults is Thyroid associated ophthalmopathy (Grave’s disease). Most common cause of Bilateral proptosis in children is Leukemia/AML(Chloroma) and neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with Orbicularis oculi paresis, lagophthalmos & insensitive cornea leading to blindness, which of the following conditions may be responsible for the same?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leprosy Leprosy causes 7th nerve palsy , so can lead to Orbicularis oculi paresis, lagophthalmos & insensitive cornea leading to blindness.

Highyeild:

Causes of decreased corneal sensations. Herpes simplex Keratitis Neuroparalytic Keratitis Leprosy Herpes zoster Ophthalmicus Absolute Glaucoma Acoustic Neuroma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Lyme's disease causes chronic granulomatous uveitis. Option: C. Ophthalmia neonatorum causes conjunctivitis. Option: D. Trachoma also leads to conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 2 month old child presented with watering of the eyes & photophobia, all of the following can cause the above symptoms, except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital districhiasis Congenital distichiasis does not lead to lacrimation and photophobia out of all the options given.

Highyeild:

Congenital distichiasis is a rare anomaly in which an extra row of cilia occupies the position of Meibomian glands which open into their follicles as ordinary sebaceous glands. These cilia are usually directed backwards and when rubbing the cornea, should be electroepilated or cryoepilated.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Congenital NLDO/ Dacryocystitis leads to lacrimation and photophobia. Option: C. Congenital entropion can also lead to lacrimation and photophobia due to irritation of the cornea. Option: D. Congenital glaucoma presents with a triad of watering, photophobia and blepharospasm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old wearing thick glasses from childhood, came with complaints of sudden onset of flashes of light in left eye. What could be the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinal detachment Photopsia, i.e. sensation of flashes of light (due to irritation of retina by vitreous movements) is seen in Retinal detachment.

Highyeild:

Prodromal Symptoms of retinal detachment include: Dark Spots (floaters) in front of the eye (due to rapid vitreous degeneration), and Photopsia, i.e. sensation of flashes of light (due to irritation of retina by vitreous movements). Symptoms of detached retina Localised relative loss in the field of vision (of detached retina) is noticed by the patient in the early stage which progresses to a total loss when peripheral detachment proceed gradually towards the macular area. Sudden appearance of a dark cloud or veil in front of the eye is complained by the patients when the detachment extends posterior equator. Sudden painless loss of vision occurs when the detachment is large and central.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. In CRAO Patient complains of sudden painless loss of vision occurring over seconds. Patients may give a history of transient visual loss (amaurosis fugax) in the past. Option: C. In CRVO there is Mild blurring of vision, which is worse on waking and improves over the day. Signs include Mild retinal venous dilatation and tortuosity; associated with few, scattered, small flame shaped haemorrhages and mild macular oedema. Option: D. In Subarachnoid hemorrhage there is extreme headache (worst headache) and no such symptoms are seen as mentioned above.

Solution:

Difference in Refractive power The optical state with equal refraction in the two eyes is termed isometropia. When the total refraction of the two eyes is unequal (> 2.5D) the condition is called anisometropia.

Highyeild:

Clinical types of anisometropia Simple anisometropia - ln this, one eye is normal (emmetropic) and the other either myopic (simple myopic anisometropia) or hypermetropic (simple hypermetropic anisometropia). Compound anisometropia- Wherein both eyes are either hypermetropic (compound hypermetropic anisometropia) or myopic (compound myopic anisometropia), but one eye is having higher refractive error than the other. Mixed anisometropia- In this, one eye is myopic and the other is hypermetropic. This is also called antimetropia. Simple astigmatic anisometropia - When one eye is normal and the other has either simple myopic or hypermetropic astigmatism. Compound astigmatic anisometropia - When both eyes are astigmatic but of unequal degree.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B,C. These options are not the correct description of anisometropia . Option: D. Difference in colour of iris is called as heterochromia iridis.

questions.text: An 80 yrs old patient presents with a painful, red right eye. On slit lamp examination, Corneal edema is seen with flare and deep anterior chamber and cataractous lens in the Right eye. IOP is 50mmHg in the left eye and 15mmHg in the right. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phacolytic glaucoma Painful red eye, along with Flare and deep anterior chamber is seen in Phacolytic glaucoma.

Highyeild:

PHACOLYTIC GLAUCOMA It is a type of secondary open angle glaucoma in which trabecular meshwork is clogged by the lens proteins, macrophages "which have phagocytosed the lens proteins, and inflammatory debris. Leakage of the lens proteins occurs through an intact capsule in the hypermature (Morgagnian) cataractous lens. Clinical features. Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to an acute rise of TOP in an eye having hypermature cataract. Anterior chamber may become deep and aqueous may contain fine white protein particles, which settle down as pseudo hypopyon. Anterior chamber angle is open on gonioscopy. Management Medical therapy to lower the IOP, followed by Extraction of the hypermature cataract lens with PCIOL implantation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. In Phacomorphic glaucoma there is secondary angle closure glaucoma and the anterior chamber will be shallow and not deep. Option: C. Malignant glaucoma is also a type of secondary angle closure glaucoma, with a shallow anterior chamber, hence it is also ruled out. Option: D. Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis is a painless condition and is seen in children and does not presents with red eye, and there is no association with cataract.
